Stops.Narrative: Hey there Explorer. My name’s Corvo. I’m a Corvus brachyrhynchos, a good ol’ American crow. But unlike your average American crow, I’m college educated! I am one of thousands of crows that call UW Bothell home, it’s getting to be a bit of a problem really. Come with me and check out the quirks of this place we roost in each day.

Stops.Title: Truly House
Stops.Hint: Your next stop is going to be The Truly House at the top of the hill.

Stops.Narrative: This old ranch house is a hold over from when this campus was agricultural land. Now it’s a standing relic to what this place used to be. Plenty of food and roosts though, so us crows keep coming.

Stops.Title: Nature Walk
Stops.Hint: Your next stop is going to be The Nature Walk behind The Guardians. Go East, downhill from the Truly House.

Stops.Narrative: Moss and fallen branches litter this pathway, it’s really like nature has taken over isn’t it?

Stops.Title: The Ancestors
Stops.Hint: Your next stop is going to be The Ancestors in front of the Nature Walk. They are wooden statues, downhill from the Nature Walk.

Stops.Narrative: These wooden statues have been here as long as I can remember! They watch as students and animals pass through the campus after year.

Stops.Title: Pollinator Field
Stops.Hint: The Pollinator Field is a patch of flowers in front of the Cascadia buildings, with three pillars showing art.

Stops.Narrative: The pollinator field has flowers and plants to attract pollinating insects. Bees love a juicy flower, and crows love a juicy insect, yum!

Stops.Title: Food Forest
Stops.Hint: Your next stop is close to the Pollinator Field, it's going to be The Food Forest by the Library.

Stops.Narrative: The food forest uses permaculture, plants put in permanently for us to enjoy over time. It has greens like kale and trees with persimmons and mulberries. Treats are seasonal, but it’s still worth the roost.

Stops.Title: Mobius
Stops.Hint: The Mobius is in the center of campus, in front of the library

Stops.Narrative: It’s the Mobius, center area of the campus, flanked by buildings on either side. We crows like to swoop down on unsuspecting students getting food from the cafe, as the space in front of the library is one of the few uncovered walkway spaces.

Stops.Title: Sports Overlook
Stops.Hint: Follow the sky bridge towards the ARC to find the Sports Overlook viewing the Wetlands Walkway.

Stops.Narrative: So many things to see overlooking the sports-field. The awning above shields visitors from rain and gives roost to birds as well. Caw!

Stops.Title: Community Gardens
Stops.Hint: Walk around the awning of the Sports Overlook/North Creek Event Center and down the stairs, then walk towards the parking lot and down the ramp.
Stops.Fact: Development of produce and agriculture in this area are a big reason that we crows are drawn here to Bothell.

Stops.Narrative: The community gardens are a great place to grab a snack (if you’re a crow). Placed by the sports fields and parking, it gets plenty of sunlight.

Stops.Title: Greenhouse
Stops.Hint: Continue along cement paved path towards the wetlands, and turn left at the veterans' memorial. Walk for a bit and turn right at the sign for the Green Conservatory.

Stops.Narrative: Plants grow here all around the year, but we birds can’t even get to them! Humans use this space to start seedlings and manage restoration projects for wildlife on campus.

Stops.Title: Wetlands Walkway
Stops.Hint: Walk back the way you came, going past the veterans' memorial and turning right at the wooden boardwalk.

Stops.Narrative: Every evening at sundown, all crows in the area descend upon the wetlands. Watch your step, and your head! The sound of a thousand crows is deafening, but worse still is the grossness of a thousand bird poops. After years of crow populations pooping into the wetlands during their evening roost, the Sammamish waterways are becoming toxic for other wildlife in the region.

stops.narrative: Hey there Explorer. My name’s Scrib. I’m an Ecpantheria scribonia, but most non-Latin speakers know me as a leopard moth. My species, in our larval form, are big fans of fine dining, especially on the flowers of Magnolia stellata, or magnolia trees. Adults, like me, feed on nectar from most flowering plants. Springtime is prime time for my favorite meal to bloom. This past spring, however, has been super cold...hello winter number two. This means that the magnolias haven’t been able to bloom as gloriously. I need you to help me find some lush magnolias please! Keep in mind, I eat other plants too, maybe you can help me find ones with flowers. My friend Piña the Pinecone is also out here somewhere. Maybe we’ll cross paths with her. Start off your exploration by venturing to the Winter Garden. Good luck!

stops.hint: Start off your exploration by venturing into the Winter Garden.
stops.fact: Did you know… The Pieris part of this plant’s name is the name of the home of the Greek Muses

stops.narrative: Hey Explorer, congrats on your first plant find! These flowers are tiny but accompanied by mighty, fiery leaves. You think I can reach the nectar?

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be near a neat little pond, head to the Japanese Maples.
stops.fact: Did you know... The latter part of the name of this tree, palmatum, was named after the palms of hands, since they look similar to the shape of the leaves

stops.narrative: These maples are so colorful! There’s tons of versions with all sorts of leaf colors. Looks like there’s no flowers for me, though…

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be near a neat little pond, head to the Japanese Maples.
stops.fact: Did you know... These are technically azaleas, but they're part of the larger plant family of rhododendron.

stops.narrative: Finally, some more food. These flowers are royally gorgeous! They’re native to Korea, they even have a festival dedicated to them.

stops.hint: Your next stop is also going to be another native Korean plant, you’ll find it in the Asiatic Maples section
stops.fact: Did you know… The Pieris part of this plant’s name is the name of the home of the Greek Muses.

stops.narrative: Not one, not two, but three flowers clustered together on this fine maple specimen! Yum.

stops.hint: The next stop on your radar is also going to be a flowering tree my favorite one at that. Next stop, Magnolias!
stops.fact: Did you know…  Magnolias, as a species, are ancient. Beetles were the first insects to pollinate them.

stops.narrative: You did it, Explorer! You found a magnolia tree! Thankfully, the flowers are in bloom and made it through the harsh winter and it looks like not many of them were frost damaged. This is going to be a feast for my species. It’s a feast for your eyes too. Look out for Piña next!

Hey there Explorer. I’m Piña the Pinecone, of the tree Pinus rigida, or the pitch pine. My family of trees has undergone a vicious attack from red turpentine beetles. Because of the drier summers, we couldn’t keep up with the lack of water reaching us. The beetles ate through our bark to reach our phloem, and the trees could not handle all the stress. Since 2005, about 40 of us at the Arboretum have been infested with beetles. Our trunks are sturdy and rigid, the rigida moniker isn’t a lie, but after droughts and beetle attacks, even our mighty bodies are taken down. I need your help. I need you to go through the Arboretum and help me find one of my surviving family members. Along the way, you’ll see lots of other plants. Hopefully, seeing these living, lush plants will encourage you to learn about all of them while they are alive, learn about biodiversity, and what YOU can do to help preserve plants! Start off by heading towards the Giant Sequoias.

stops.hint: Start off by heading towards the Giant Sequoias.
stops.fact: Did you know… Giant sequoias are one of the oldest living species on Earth, with the oldest recorded one being around 3500 years old.

stops.narrative: What a huge specimen! My family doesn’t grow nearly as big. This guy has probably been around longer than most people working at the Arboretum. I wonder what he’s seen…

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be straight ahead in the Camellia section.
stops.fact: Did you know... Camellias are important symbolic plants in Japan and China. In China, they’re lucky symbols during Chinese New year.

stops.narrative: This variety of the common camellia is so vibrant! It’s always nice to see such a happy bloom when our environment is usually gloomy.

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be down a nearby staircase, you’ll see some more lovely flowers.
stops.fact: Did you know... These are technically azaleas, but they're part of the larger plant family of rhododendrons.

stops.narrative: These little pink flowers are Washington’s state flower. They’re common along the West Coast, and their cousins, other rhododendrons and azaleas, are common throughout the Arboretum.

stops.hint: Your next stop is along the winding path, just stay straight on. Look out for bright organge flowers.
stops.fact: Did you know… this flower hybrid was developd in the 1950’s in Portland, Oregon.

stops.narrative: Nice job finding this plant, Explorer! It’s a hybrid and beautiful flower.

stops.hint: Your next stop looks like it’s going to be exciting for me! Keep going!
stops.fact: Did you know…The pitch pine grows well in soils that most other plants could not thrive in, like swampy and acidic soil. Our trunks are usually quite twisted and irregular, we grow to our own beat.

stops.narrative: Hey, it’s a family member! I’m so excited to see an elder tree that’s growing healthily. Looks like some of my fellow pinecones are also developing quite well. Thanks so much for all the help. Thanks for all the help, Explorer! All of this Arboretum exploration has hopefully allowed you to learn a lot about the incredible biodiversity that exists here. You can take your knowledge and apply it at home in your community. You can read up about plant care and start your own garden, responsibly planting a variety of lush plants is a great way to add to the biodiversity of your area. You can talk to the lovely folks at the Arboretum about further learning opportunities as well! Visit arboretumfoundation.org for more info.

Hey there Explorer, nice to meet you, can you see me up here hovering around? I can be hard to miss. My name’s Rufus, and I’m a rufous hummingbird. I’m not really from around here.... I’ve been travelling for so long now, I’ve migrated up to the PNW from Mexico. I still have quite a ways to go, I’m actually heading to Alaska for the season. All this travelling makes me extremely hungry, and my small self needs flower nectar to survive. Some flowering plants throughout the Arboretum may have bloomed early due to changes in climate, so I need you to help me find plants that are currently in bloom and not too frost-bitten. Hopefully we can find a feast, and you can learn about the incredible plants that are all around you!

stops.hint: Start off on the path near the pines, you’ll see some smaller trees that will be flowering.
stops.fact: Did you know…  this tree was discovered in 1931 and is native to China.

stops.narrative: Looks like there’s a few little blooms on this tree, just a bit bigger than me

stops.stopname: Azalea Way, up on an incline
stops.hint: Go up a small grove incline, you’ll see some vibrant shrubs.
stops.fact: Did you know…  the dark red spots in the middle of the petals of this flower are used by bees and other pollinators to guide them to the pollen.

stops.narrative: Now these are some yummy flowers! I’ll be drowning in nectar.

stops.hint: Go down further towards a serene pond, you’ll see a colorful tree.
stops.fact: Did you know…  Acer in Latin means sharp, referring to the shape of the leaves.

stops.narrative: Reds and greens abound! I could blend in pretty well against this tree. No flowers for me though!

stops.hint: Keep going further down Azalea Way, you’ll see some big buttercup-like flowers.
stops.fact: Did you know…this type of dogwood’s flower is the provincial flower of British Columbia.

stops.narrative: These flowers look tasty, almost like overgrown buttercups. They’re so high up the tree, I’ll have to do a lot of hovering to get to them.

stops.hint: Go down to the end of Azalea Way, you’re almost done.
stops.fact: Did you know… some rhododendrons produce toxic pollen and nectar, and honey made from the specific pollen can be hallucinogenic to humans.

stops.narrative: Hey looks like you’re all done down this path! You’ve found me a bunch of yummy flowers, thanks so much! Thanks for all the help, Explorer! I’m gonna have sooo many yummy options to feast on before I head off to Alaska. We’re lucky to have so many beautiful plants around us to appreciate, and eat! I hope along the way I have more flowers to eat. This shows us that the diversity of plants is super important for animals like me. You can help migrating species like me by planting a diversity of plants in your own garden.
